descriptionSet.description: The image shows a view of Standing Camp, Ranikhet. A row of buildings grouped together and various tents pitched near the buildings can be seen. Trees surround the buildings and in the distance mountains can be seen.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: The image shows a view of Standing Camp, Ranikhet. A row of buildings grouped together and various tents pitched near the buildings can be seen. Trees surround the buildings and in the distance mountains can be seen. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The point of view here is from an unspecified elevation, surveying the expanse of the camp. In effect, this is the point of view of a colonial subject who is keeping an eye on other colonial subjects. The location of Ranikhet is significant as well. Ranikhet was a satellite station, subordinate to Nainital (which is at a slightly higher elevation as well), the provincial hill capital of the United Provinces. It is as if Ranikhet is under the gaze of Nainital. Thus not only was surveillance necessary for controlling the native, it was also necessary to be exercised within colonial society. These are not images of triumphant ownership of pretty views and potential wealth, but rather the gestures of an enterprise that doesn't quite work and needs to defend itself. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Ranikhet was established as a cantonment station in the 1860s. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)
related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" (gs)
